Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Situation2: They identify a malfunctioning pool filtration system that could endanger swimmers’ safety if not repaired immediately.
Story:
I was just about to start my shift as a lifeguard when my phone buzzed. It was Sam, my best friend, looking frazzled on a video call. “Hey, can you help me? I’m totally lost with this furniture. The instructions make no sense.” I could see the half-built bookshelf behind him, pieces scattered everywhere. I knew he’d been having a rough week, and I wanted to be there for him—he’d do the same for me.

But as I glanced over at the pool, I noticed the water looked cloudy. I checked the filtration system and realized it wasn’t working right. If I didn’t fix it now, someone could get hurt, and it was my responsibility to keep everyone safe. My supervisor always emphasized that equipment maintenance was non-negotiable.

Sam’s call kept ringing. I felt torn—my friend needed me, but so did the swimmers. The pressure built in my chest as I weighed the expectations: be the reliable friend or the vigilant lifeguard. I stared at my phone, heart pounding, caught between two worlds that both needed me right now.
